lines.text: Gringo? I don't know if that's a step up or a step down from some other things I've been called.
I'm gonna' build me a chapel.
Say, where'd you get all the material?
A man, he gives wood... bricks. In time, what does he get? A chapel... a place where his children can receive the sacraments. To these men, for their children to have faith, it is important.
To me, it is insurance. To me, life is here on this earth. I cannot see further, so I cannot believe further. But, if they are right about the hereafter, I have paid my insurance, Senor.

[the morning after a fiesta]
Well, you are awake?
[throws a cup of cold water in his face]
Why'd you go and do that?
The women last night, they say that is the only thing when a man has been mixing wine with tequila!
I'm gonna mix you with tequila!

[the final English lesson]
Oh, *I* built a chapel...
Old Mother gonna feed the slaves?
Kiwani's, what kind of animal is that?

[upon first meeting Homer]
God is good. He has sent me a big strong man.

[one of the nuns has just given Homer his breakfast; one fried egg and a half cup of milk]
That's a Catholic breakfast, ain't it?
Oh! Why couldn't they have asked me to build a bathtub? With nice, *hot* water?
I cannot see further and I cannot believe further.

[turns to see a Mexican couple with a beautiful chandelier]
Yes? Oh my. Well, we're going to have to find someplace special for this. Thank you.

[wife takes his hand in gratitude]
Well, take this to Mother Maria.
